prompt_text:
Draft a clear, welcoming volunteer role description for [ORGANIZATION NAME] that helps busy nonprofit teams recruit well-matched volunteers.

QUICK INTAKE (copy/paste and fill; leave “TBD” if unknown)
- Organization: [ORGANIZATION NAME], mission/cause: [MISSION/CAUSE]
- Volunteer type: [ONE-TIME EVENT / ONGOING DIRECT SERVICE / SKILLED-PRO BONO / VIRTUAL / BOARD-LEADERSHIP]
- Role title: [ROLE TITLE]
- Impact metric: [e.g., “serve 50 meals per shift,” “support 12 students weekly”]
- Time & place: [X hours/week], [duration], [schedule/flexibility], [location], [on-site/remote/hybrid]
- Supervisor: [SUPERVISOR TITLE]
- Training/support: [TRAINING PROVIDED]; materials/resources: [LIST]; stipends/reimbursements: [MILEAGE/PARKING/MEALS or “None”]
- Screening: [e.g., background check—cost covered by ORG; none]
- Application: [APPLICATION LINK/EMAIL], response time: [e.g., within 5 business days], target start: [DATE or Rolling]
- Inclusion/accessibility contact: [NAME/EMAIL/PHONE]
- Contact/signature: [CONTACT NAME], [TITLE], [PHONE/EMAIL]
- Tone: [FORMAL / WARM / CASUAL]

If a field is blank, propose a sensible default and flag it in [brackets]. If something doesn’t apply, write “Not applicable” or omit.

STRUCTURE & CONTENT (output must use these 9 numbered headings)
1) Role Title
2) Brief Overview (2–3 sentences)
- What the volunteer will do and why it matters.
- Include impact: “Each shift helps [IMPACT METRIC], advancing [MISSION/CAUSE].”
3) Responsibilities (4–6 bullets)
- Be concrete. GOOD: “Greet visitors and check them in using our sign-in iPad.” BAD: “Support front desk operations.”
- Tailor to [VOLUNTEER TYPE] (e.g., one-time event = day-of tasks; board = governance/strategy; skilled = defined deliverables; virtual = tools/platforms).
4) Time Commitment
- State: [HOURS/WEEK], [DURATION], [SCHEDULE/FLEXIBILITY], [LOCATION], [ON-SITE/REMOTE/HYBRID].
5) Qualifications
- Required (must-have): keep minimal.
- Preferred (nice-to-have): end with “Don’t meet every preferred item? We encourage you to apply.”
6) Training & Support
- Note training, supervision, materials. Add reimbursements/stipends if applicable; if none, say “No out-of-pocket costs.”
7) Screening & Requirements
- State simply (e.g., “Background check—cost covered by [ORG NAME]”). Include age/confidentiality only if essential. If none, write “No background check required.”
8) Inclusion & Accessibility
- Always include: “We welcome volunteers of all backgrounds and abilities. To request accommodations, contact [NAME/EMAIL/PHONE].”
9) Application Process & Contact
- How to apply, response time, target start date, and “Posted by [CONTACT NAME], [TITLE], [PHONE/EMAIL], [ORGANIZATION NAME].”

STYLE & TONE
- Length: 250–350 words total; prioritize clarity over strict count.
- Reading level: 8th–10th grade; short sentences; plain words.
- Tone: [FORMAL / WARM / CASUAL] (choose one and use consistently).
- Format: plain text with numbered headings and bullets; include hyperlinks in parentheses for digital use; spell out URLs for print.

EXAMPLE SNIPPET (tone: WARM, ~50 words)
“As a Weekend Pantry Greeter, you’ll welcome neighbors, check them in on our iPad, and answer simple questions. Each 3-hour shift helps 60 households access fresh, healthy food—moving us closer to a hunger-free community. We’ll train you on our check-in app and have a staff lead nearby for support.”

MUST DO
- Be honest about time and requirements.
- Make tasks specific and scannable.
- Use inclusive, welcoming language.

NEVER DO
- Use legalese, clichés (“rockstar”), or vague phrases (“other duties as assigned”).
- Create unnecessary barriers in “Required.”

QUALITY CHECK
Before finalizing, ensure someone could read this in 90 seconds and know if they’re a fit, what they’ll do, and how to apply.

OUTPUT
Produce one polished role description following the 9 headings above. Do not include tips or commentary in the final output.

scenarios.name: Small Community Org
scenarios.description: Rural, volunteer-driven food access nonprofit in the Flint Hills of Kansas. Small staff, supported by local churches, small businesses, and county grants; serves low-income families, seniors, and farmworkers.

scenarios.description: West Coast conservation nonprofit with 120+ staff and regional offices. Backed by major donors, foundations, and corporate partners; manages large-scale habitat restoration projects.

values.MISSION/CAUSE: Protect and restore Pacific Coast habitats so wildlife and communities thrive.

values.TITLE: Director of Conservation Data

outputs.content:
## 1) Role Title
Mobile Pantry Assistant

## 2) Brief Overview
As a Mobile Pantry Assistant, you’ll be a friendly face helping neighbors access fresh, healthy groceries at our rotating rural sites. Each shift helps 60 households receive fresh groceries, advancing our mission to reduce rural hunger in Chase and Lyon counties by bringing fresh, healthy groceries directly to neighbors.

## 3) Responsibilities
* Warmly greet neighbors, assisting them with check-in using our mobile app on an iPad.
* Help set up and tear down mobile pantry stations, carefully handling food boxes and supplies.
* Distribute pre-packed grocery boxes and assist neighbors with carrying items to their vehicles.
* Answer basic questions about the pantry services and direct neighbors to the Pantry Coordinator when needed.
* Maintain a clean and organized distribution area during and after each shift.
* Potentially drive the agency van to designated pantry sites (if qualified and interested).

## 4) Time Commitment
We ask for 3 hours per week, with a minimum commitment of 3 months. Shifts are Saturdays from 8:30–11:30 a.m. Volunteers are asked to choose at least 2 Saturdays per month. We meet at the Strong City Community Center and travel to rotating rural sites in Chase & Lyon counties, KS. This is an on-site role.

## 5) Qualifications
**Required:**
* Ability to lift up to 25 pounds comfortably.
* A friendly and compassionate demeanor.

**Preferred:**
* Valid driver's license and a clean driving record (if interested in driving the agency van).
* Experience with mobile device applications.
* Don’t meet every preferred item? We encourage you to apply.

## 6) Training & Support
You'll receive a 1-hour orientation to learn about our mission and operations. On-the-spot training will be provided for using the check-in app and safe lifting techniques. We provide a safety vest, gloves, an iPad for check-in, a name badge, and bottled water during your shift. Mileage reimbursement is available for designated drivers at $0.45/mile, and free parking is provided.

## 7) Screening & Requirements
No background check is required for this role. An MVR (Motor Vehicle Record) check will be conducted by Flint Hills Neighbors Pantry at our cost if you are interested in driving the agency van.

## 8) Inclusion & Accessibility
We welcome volunteers of all backgrounds and abilities. To request accommodations, contact Maria Lopez, access@flinthillspantry.org, 620-555-0147.

## 9) Application Process & Contact
To apply, please visit https://flinthillspantry.org/volunteer. We aim to respond to all applications within 3 business days. We have rolling start dates, so you can begin making a difference soon!
Posted by Evan Carter, Pantry Coordinator, 620-555-0129, evan@flinthillspantry.org, Flint Hills Neighbors Pantry.

evaluation.reasoning: This is a highly polished, professional volunteer role description that successfully balances warmth with clarity. It follows the template precisely, provides concrete details that help candidates self-screen, and maintains accessibility throughout. Minor areas for improvement include slightly generic phrasing in a few spots and one small structural inconsistency.
strengths: Excellent concrete task descriptions (e.g., 'Warmly greet neighbors, assisting them with check-in using our mobile app on an iPad' vs. vague 'support operations')
Strong adherence to template structure with all 9 required headings properly formatted and complete
Appropriate warm tone throughout that feels welcoming without being overly casual or unprofessional
Clear, honest time commitment and flexibility parameters that help volunteers understand exactly what's expected
Effective use of impact metric integration in the overview ('Each shift helps 60 households receive fresh groceries')
Inclusive language in qualifications section with encouraging 'Don't meet every preferred item?' statement
Proper handling of screening requirements with clear distinction between general volunteers and van drivers
Accessibility contact information prominently displayed with multiple contact methods
Reading level appears appropriate (8th-10th grade) with short sentences and plain language throughout
weaknesses: The phrase 'making a difference' in section 9 is slightly clichéd, though not egregious
Word count appears to be approximately 320-330 words, which is within range but on the higher end—could be tightened slightly
The 'potentially drive the agency van' bullet in Responsibilities could be clearer that this is optional/for interested volunteers only

outputs.content:
# Mobile Pantry Assistant

## 1) Role Title
**Mobile Pantry Assistant**

## 2) Brief Overview
As a Mobile Pantry Assistant, you'll help set up our mobile grocery distribution sites, greet neighbors warmly, assist with food selection, and carry groceries to vehicles. Each shift helps 60 households receive fresh groceries, advancing our mission to reduce rural hunger in Chase and Lyon counties by bringing fresh, healthy groceries directly to neighbors.

## 3) Responsibilities
- Unload the pantry van and set up tables, tents, and food displays at rotating rural sites
- Greet neighbors, check them in using our iPad app, and answer questions about available groceries
- Help neighbors select fresh produce, dairy, proteins, and shelf-stable items based on household size
- Carry grocery bags and boxes to neighbors' vehicles
- Restock tables throughout the distribution and repack leftover items at the end
- Work alongside 4–6 other volunteers and follow direction from the Pantry Coordinator

## 4) Time Commitment
**3 hours per week, 3-month minimum commitment.** Saturdays, 8:30–11:30 a.m.; choose at least 2 Saturdays per month. We rotate among rural sites in Chase and Lyon counties, Kansas—meet at Strong City Community Center each Saturday morning. This is an on-site role.

## 5) Qualifications
**Required:**
- Able to lift and carry up to 25 pounds
- Comfortable working outdoors in varying weather
- Friendly and respectful with people from all backgrounds

**Preferred:**
- Experience with customer service or community events
- Familiarity with the Flint Hills region

Don't meet every preferred item? We encourage you to apply.

## 6) Training & Support
You'll receive a 1-hour orientation and on-the-spot training for our check-in app and safe lifting techniques. We provide a safety vest, gloves, iPad for check-in, name badge, and bottled water. Mileage reimbursement at $0.45 per mile is available if you're a designated driver for our agency van. Free parking at all sites.

## 7) Screening & Requirements
No background check required. If you're interested in driving the agency van, a Motor Vehicle Record (MVR) check is required—cost covered by Flint Hills Neighbors Pantry.

## 8) Inclusion & Accessibility
We welcome volunteers of all backgrounds and abilities. To request accommodations, contact Maria Lopez at access@flinthillspantry.org or 620-555-0147.

## 9) Application Process & Contact
Apply online at https://flinthillspantry.org/volunteer (or flinthillspantry.org/volunteer). We'll respond within 3 business days. Start dates are rolling—join us any Saturday!

**Posted by Evan Carter, Pantry Coordinator**  
620-555-0129 | evan@flinthillspantry.org | Flint Hills Neighbors Pantry

evaluation.reasoning: This is an exceptionally strong volunteer role description that successfully balances warmth with professionalism. It provides concrete, actionable details while maintaining an inviting tone appropriate for a rural community nonprofit. The output demonstrates excellent adherence to the template structure and creates a genuinely useful recruitment tool.
strengths: Perfect tone execution—warm and welcoming without being overly casual or corporate; phrases like 'greet neighbors warmly' and 'Don't meet every preferred item? We encourage you to apply' create genuine inclusivity
Highly specific, scannable responsibilities—'Carry grocery bags and boxes to neighbors' vehicles' and 'check them in using our iPad app' give clear mental pictures of the work
Excellent use of impact framing—the '60 households' metric appears in the overview and connects directly to the mission statement
Realistic and honest about physical requirements (25 pounds, outdoor work, varying weather) without creating unnecessary barriers
Strong practical details—mileage reimbursement rate, meeting location, free parking, materials provided—answers questions volunteers actually have
Appropriate length (approximately 320 words) that respects the 90-second readability test
Clean formatting with proper heading hierarchy and scannable bullets
Inclusive language throughout, with specific accessibility contact information
weaknesses: Minor: The final line 'Category: programs' appears to be metadata that shouldn't be in the final volunteer-facing document
Very minor: Could potentially specify what 'varying weather' means in Kansas context (heat, cold, rain) for out-of-state applicants, though this may be unnecessary for local recruitment

outputs.content:
1) Role Title
Mobile Pantry Assistant

2) Brief Overview
Join Flint Hills Neighbors Pantry to bring fresh, healthy groceries directly to rural neighbors. As a Mobile Pantry Assistant, you’ll help set up, welcome households, check them in, and place groceries into carts and cars with care. Each shift helps 60 households receive fresh groceries, advancing our mission to reduce rural hunger in Chase and Lyon counties by bringing fresh, healthy groceries directly to neighbors.

3) Responsibilities
- Greet neighbors with warmth and check them in using our iPad sign-in app.
- Sort and pack produce and pantry staples; restock items during distribution.
- Load groceries safely into carts and vehicles; offer basic program information.
- Keep the line moving and the site safe (traffic flow, cones, safety vests).
- Set up and take down tables, tents, and signage; track simple counts as directed.
- Optional: Serve as a designated driver for the agency van to/from sites (training provided).

4) Time Commitment
- 3 hours/week, 3 months minimum, Saturdays 8:30–11:30 a.m.; choose at least 2 Saturdays/month
- Rotating rural sites in Chase & Lyon counties, KS (meet at Strong City Community Center)
- On-site

5) Qualifications
- Required: Friendly and reliable; able to follow instructions and work as a team. Comfortable using or learning an iPad. Able to lift up to 25 lbs safely—or choose a low-lift role.
- Preferred: Customer service experience; conversational Spanish; experience with food handling or events; willing to drive agency van (valid license). Don’t meet every preferred item? We encourage you to apply.

6) Training & Support
- 1-hour orientation; on-the-spot training for check-in app and safe lifting.
- Supervision: Pantry Coordinator on site.
- Materials provided: Safety vest, gloves, iPad for check-in, name badge, bottled water.
- Reimbursements: Mileage for designated drivers at $0.45/mile; free parking.

7) Screening & Requirements
- No background check required.
- MVR check required only if driving the agency van—cost covered by Flint Hills Neighbors Pantry.

8) Inclusion & Accessibility
We welcome volunteers of all backgrounds and abilities. Many tasks can be done seated or with light lifting. To request accommodations, contact Maria Lopez, access@flinthillspantry.org, 620-555-0147.

9) Application Process & Contact
Apply at flinthillspantry.org/volunteer (https://flinthillspantry.org/volunteer). We respond within 3 business days. Target start: Rolling.
Posted by Evan Carter, Pantry Coordinator, 620-555-0129, evan@flinthillspantry.org, Flint Hills Neighbors Pantry.

evaluation.reasoning: This is a highly polished, professional volunteer role description that successfully balances warmth with clarity. It follows the template precisely, provides concrete details that help candidates self-screen, and uses inclusive, accessible language throughout. Minor opportunities exist to enhance authenticity with more rural-specific voice.
strengths: Excellent concrete task descriptions (e.g., 'Greet neighbors with warmth and check them in using our iPad sign-in app' vs. vague generalities)
Strong accessibility language that goes beyond boilerplate ('Many tasks can be done seated or with light lifting')
Clear, honest time commitment and flexibility parameters that respect volunteer boundaries
Effective use of impact metric integration in the overview
Appropriate warm tone throughout without being overly casual or corporate
Smart handling of the optional driver role without creating confusion
Scannable format that passes the 90-second comprehension test
Inclusive qualifications section that minimizes barriers while being realistic
weaknesses: The phrase 'advancing our mission to reduce rural hunger...' in section 2 creates slight redundancy by repeating the full mission statement verbatim—could be tightened to 'moving us closer to hunger-free rural communities'
Word count is approximately 320 words, which is within range but on the higher end—section 3 has 6 bullets when 4-5 might be more scannable
Minor authenticity gap: the voice is warm but slightly polished for a small rural org—phrases like 'conversational Spanish' feel more corporate than 'basic Spanish' or 'some Spanish'

outputs.content:
Here's a welcoming volunteer role description for TCREN:

1) Role Title
Virtual ESL Conversation Partner

2) Brief Overview
Lend a friendly ear and help adults learning English practice their skills. As a Virtual ESL Conversation Partner, you'll meet with learners to build their confidence in speaking. Each shift helps support 2 adult learners in 2 sessions weekly to build English confidence, advancing Twin Cities Refugee Education Network’s mission to partner with refugee and immigrant adults to advance English, career, and digital skills for family-sustaining jobs.

3) Responsibilities
* Lead engaging one-on-one or small group conversations with adult learners.
* Utilize provided lesson plans and conversation prompts to guide discussions.
* Offer encouragement and positive feedback to help learners feel comfortable.
* Be a consistent and reliable presence for your assigned learners each week.
* Track learner progress and attendance in TCREN’s [online system].

4) Time Commitment
We're looking for a commitment of 2 hours per week for 6 months, on weeknights between 6–9 p.m. CT. You'll set a consistent 2-hour window that works for you and your learners, all done remotely via Zoom.

5) Qualifications
*Required:*
* A desire to help adult refugee and immigrant learners.
* Strong communication and listening skills.
* Access to reliable internet and a computer with a webcam and microphone.
*Commitment to a 6-month volunteering period.
*Preferred:*
* Experience working with diverse populations or teaching/tutoring.
* Familiarity with Zoom for online meetings.

Don’t meet every preferred item? We encourage you to apply.

6) Training & Support
You’ll receive a 2-hour online training on trauma-informed tutoring and using Zoom tools. We also offer a monthly mentor circle for ongoing support and connection. We’ll provide all the materials you need, including lesson plans, conversation prompts, Zoom Pro access, and pronunciation resources. No out-of-pocket costs will be incurred.

7) Screening & Requirements
A background check will be conducted, with the cost covered by Twin Cities Refugee Education Network (TCREN).

8) Inclusion & Accessibility
We welcome volunteers of all backgrounds and abilities. To request accommodations, contact Amina Warsame at access@tcren.org or 612-555-2270.

9) Application Process & Contact
Ready to make a difference? Apply online at https://tcren.org/volunteer/apply. We’ll respond to your application within 5 business days. Our next cohorts start monthly, with the next target start date on December 2, 2025.

Posted by Jordan Kim, Volunteer Manager, 612-555-2211, jordan.kim@tcren.org, Twin Cities Refugee Education Network (TCREN).

evaluation.reasoning: The output is well-structured and welcoming, with authentic language that would appeal to potential volunteers. However, it contains several technical issues: the word count exceeds guidelines (387 vs. 250-350), includes an undefined placeholder '[online system]', and has an awkward impact statement repetition in section 2. The casual tone is mostly appropriate but occasionally slips into more formal phrasing.
strengths: Excellent concrete, scannable responsibilities that clearly show what volunteers will actually do
Strong inclusive language and welcoming tone throughout, particularly in qualifications section
Complete contact information and clear application process with all required details
Authentic voice that sounds genuinely inviting rather than corporate or robotic
Good use of trauma-informed language appropriate for refugee education context
weaknesses: Word count is 387 words, exceeding the 250-350 target by 37 words, reducing scannability
Section 2 awkwardly repeats the full impact metric and mission verbatim rather than integrating naturally
Contains undefined placeholder '[online system]' in responsibilities that should have been specified or removed
Required qualifications includes '6-month commitment' which duplicates time commitment section and creates unnecessary barrier
Opening phrase 'Lend a friendly ear' is slightly cliché given the prompt's instruction to avoid clichés
Some tonal inconsistency—'incurred' in section 6 is formal language that doesn't match casual tone

outputs.content:
# Virtual ESL Conversation Partner

## 1) Role Title
**Virtual ESL Conversation Partner**

## 2) Brief Overview
You'll meet one-on-one with adult refugee and immigrant learners via Zoom to practice real-world English conversation—helping them build confidence for job interviews, parent-teacher conferences, and everyday life. Each week, you'll support 2 adult learners in 2 sessions to build English confidence, advancing TCREN's mission to partner with refugee and immigrant adults to advance English, career, and digital skills for family-sustaining jobs.

## 3) Responsibilities
- Meet with each of your two assigned learners once per week for a 1-hour Zoom conversation session
- Use provided conversation prompts and lesson plans to guide discussions on topics like work, family, health, and community
- Practice pronunciation, listening, and speaking skills through structured activities and casual chat
- Track attendance and note learner progress in our simple online form after each session
- Attend one monthly virtual mentor circle (30 minutes) to share ideas and troubleshoot with other volunteers
- Communicate respectfully and use trauma-informed practices covered in training

## 4) Time Commitment
**2 hours per week for 6 months.** Choose a consistent 2-hour window between 6–9 p.m. CT on weeknights (Monday–Thursday). Sessions happen remotely via Zoom from wherever you have reliable internet.

## 5) Qualifications
**Required:**
- Fluent in English (native or near-native speaker)
- Reliable internet connection and quiet space for Zoom calls
- Comfortable using Zoom (screen share, breakout features)
- Patient, encouraging, and culturally curious

**Preferred:**
- Experience teaching, tutoring, or working with adult learners
- Second language yourself or cross-cultural experience
- Familiarity with refugee/immigrant communities

Don't meet every preferred item? We encourage you to apply.

## 6) Training & Support
You'll complete a 2-hour online training covering trauma-informed tutoring techniques and Zoom tools before your first session. We provide weekly lesson plans, conversation prompts, pronunciation resources, and Zoom Pro access. The Adult Education Program Manager checks in regularly, and you'll join a monthly mentor circle with fellow volunteers. No out-of-pocket costs.

## 7) Screening & Requirements
Background check required—cost covered by TCREN.

## 8) Inclusion & Accessibility
We welcome volunteers of all backgrounds and abilities. To request accommodations, contact Amina Warsame, access@tcren.org, 612-555-2270.

## 9) Application Process & Contact
Apply at https://tcren.org/volunteer/apply. We'll respond within 5 business days. Monthly cohorts start throughout the year; next start date is December 2, 2025.

Posted by Jordan Kim, Volunteer Manager, 612-555-2211, jordan.kim@tcren.org, Twin Cities Refugee Education Network (TCREN).

evaluation.reasoning: This is a highly polished, professional volunteer role description that successfully balances warmth with clarity. It follows the template precisely, provides concrete details that help candidates self-screen, and maintains an accessible, welcoming tone throughout. Minor improvements could include slightly more distinctive voice to avoid sounding template-generated.
strengths: Excellent concrete specificity in responsibilities (e.g., '1-hour Zoom conversation session,' 'simple online form,' 'monthly virtual mentor circle (30 minutes)')
Strong impact framing that connects individual volunteer action to organizational mission without being preachy
Appropriate casual tone that remains professional—uses 'you'll' contractions, conversational phrasing, and avoids jargon
Qualifications section strikes good balance between requirements and accessibility, with encouraging language for preferred items
Time commitment section is crystal clear about expectations (specific days, duration, platform, flexibility)
Includes all 9 required headings with appropriate content under each
Word count (~340) falls within target range while remaining scannable
Trauma-informed language is appropriately woven in without being performative
weaknesses: Brief Overview runs slightly long at 3+ sentences when template calls for 2-3; could be tightened
The phrase 'culturally curious' in qualifications, while well-intentioned, could be seen as slightly vague or potentially tokenizing—'open to learning from diverse perspectives' might be clearer
Minor redundancy: 'remotely via Zoom' appears in both sections 2 and 4

outputs.content:
1) Role Title
Virtual ESL Conversation Partner

2) Brief Overview
Join Twin Cities Refugee Education Network (TCREN) to practice English with adult refugee and immigrant learners over Zoom. You’ll guide friendly, low-stress conversations and use simple lesson prompts. Each shift helps support 2 adult learners in 2 sessions weekly to build English confidence, advancing our mission to partner with refugee and immigrant adults to advance English, career, and digital skills for family-sustaining jobs.

3) Responsibilities
- Host two 50–55 minute conversation sessions each week on Zoom with assigned adult learners.
- Use provided lesson plans, prompts, and pronunciation tools to spark practice and confidence.
- Track attendance and jot brief notes after each session in our online form.
- Use Zoom features (chat, screen share, captions) to support different learning styles.
- Communicate schedule changes, tech issues, or learner concerns to the Adult Education Program Manager.
- Join a monthly virtual mentor circle to share tips and get support.

4) Time Commitment
- 2 hours/week for 6 months.
- Weeknights between 6–9 p.m. CT; set a consistent 2-hour window.
- Remote via Zoom.

5) Qualifications
Required:
- Clear spoken English and a warm, patient style.
- Reliable internet, camera, and a quiet space.
- Comfortable using Zoom (we’ll train on features).
- Able to commit to a steady weeknight schedule for 6 months.

Preferred:
- Experience with ESL/ELL tutoring, teaching, or cross-cultural work.
- Familiarity with trauma-informed approaches.
- Multilingual a plus.
Don’t meet every preferred item? We encourage you to apply.

6) Training & Support
- 2-hour online training on trauma-informed tutoring and Zoom tools.
- Ongoing support from the Adult Education Program Manager and a monthly mentor circle.
- Materials provided: lesson plans, conversation prompts, pronunciation resources, Zoom Pro access.
- No out-of-pocket costs.

7) Screening & Requirements
- Background check—cost covered by Twin Cities Refugee Education Network (TCREN).

8) Inclusion & Accessibility
We welcome volunteers of all backgrounds and abilities. To request accommodations, contact Amina Warsame, access@tcren.org, 612-555-2270.

9) Application Process & Contact
Apply at https://tcren.org/volunteer/apply (or search “TCREN volunteer apply”). We’ll respond within 5 business days. Monthly cohorts; next start December 2, 2025.
Posted by Jordan Kim, Volunteer Manager, 612-555-2211, jordan.kim@tcren.org, Twin Cities Refugee Education Network (TCREN).

evaluation.reasoning: This is a strong, professional volunteer role description that successfully balances warmth with clarity. It follows the template precisely, uses concrete language, and provides all essential information a potential volunteer needs. Minor weaknesses include slight wordiness in the overview and a small math inconsistency in the time commitment.
strengths: Excellent concrete, scannable responsibilities (e.g., 'Host two 50–55 minute conversation sessions' vs. vague 'support learners')
Casual tone executed consistently and appropriately—friendly without being unprofessional ('jot brief notes,' 'spark practice')
Strong inclusion of practical details: Zoom features, trauma-informed approach, monthly mentor circles show organizational maturity
Impact metric integrated naturally into overview without feeling forced
Qualifications section strikes good balance—minimal required items, encouraging language for preferred
Application section provides both URL and search instruction for accessibility
weaknesses: Brief Overview is slightly wordy at 4 sentences when 2–3 requested; could tighten the mission statement integration
Minor math inconsistency: '2 hours/week' stated, but 'two 50–55 minute sessions' = ~1.7–1.8 hours; should clarify if 2 hours includes prep/notes or adjust
Responsibilities bullet 6 (monthly mentor circle) could move to Training & Support section where it's already mentioned, creating slight redundancy

outputs.content:
1) Role Title
GIS Mapping Analyst (Pro Bono)

2) Brief Overview
The GIS Mapping Analyst (Pro Bono) will play a crucial role in enhancing our conservation efforts by providing specialized mapping expertise. Each project undertaken will produce high-quality habitat maps essential for guiding restoration initiatives across significant acreage, advancing our mission to protect and restore Pacific Coast habitats so wildlife and communities thrive.

3) Responsibilities
* Design and create professional habitat maps using ArcGIS Pro.
* Analyze spatial data related to ecological features and restoration project sites.
* Collaborate with the conservation team to understand mapping requirements and project goals.
* Ensure map outputs adhere to established data governance and branding guidelines.
* Produce final map products and associated metadata for internal use and reporting.

4) Time Commitment
This role requires approximately 6 hours per week for a period of 12 weeks. Hours are flexible, with a mandatory weekly check-in meeting on Tuesdays from 1–2 p.m. PT. This is a Hybrid role, primarily remote, with an optional desk available at our San Francisco Headquarters.

5) Qualifications
*Required:*
* Proficiency in ArcGIS Pro or ArcGIS Online.
* Experience with spatial data analysis and cartographic principles.
* Ability to work independently and meet project deadlines.

*Preferred:*
* Bachelor’s degree in Geography, Environmental Science, or a related field.
* Experience with conservation or environmental mapping projects.
* Familiarity with habitat restoration concepts.

Don’t meet every preferred item? We encourage you to apply.

6) Training & Support
Volunteers will receive a comprehensive project briefing, onboarding for ArcGIS Online/Pro, and an orientation to our data governance policies. We will provide an ArcGIS Pro license, a data dictionary, branded map templates, and secure access to necessary data. No stipends or reimbursements are provided for this role.

7) Screening & Requirements
Volunteers will be required to sign a volunteer agreement and a confidentiality/non-disclosure agreement (NDA). No background check is required for this position.

8) Inclusion & Accessibility
We welcome volunteers of all backgrounds and abilities. To request accommodations, please contact Leah Chen at inclusion@pacifictrails.org or 415-555-0198.

9) Application Process & Contact
To apply for this role, please visit https://pacifictrails.org/volunteer/gis-analyst. We will respond to all applications within 7 business days. This is a rolling start position, with the next project kickoff scheduled for January 13, 2026.

Posted by Ravi Patel, Director of Conservation Data, 415-555-0172, ravi.patel@pacifictrails.org, Pacific Trails Conservancy.

evaluation.reasoning: This is a strong, professional volunteer role description that follows the template structure well and would be immediately usable by the nonprofit. The formal tone is appropriate for a skilled pro bono role, and the content is specific and actionable. However, there are minor issues with word count (exceeds 350 words), impact metric placement, and some slightly verbose phrasing that could be tightened.
strengths: Excellent adherence to the 9-heading structure with all required sections present and properly formatted
Specific, concrete responsibilities that clearly define the role (e.g., 'Design and create professional habitat maps using ArcGIS Pro' rather than vague tasks)
Strong formal tone consistency throughout that matches the professional nature of a skilled GIS role at an established organization
Comprehensive training and support section that clearly outlines what the volunteer will receive (license, templates, data access)
Appropriate qualifications balance—minimal required skills with encouraging language for preferred items
Clear time commitment details including the hybrid flexibility that skilled professionals often need
All contact information, accessibility statement, and application details are complete and well-organized
weaknesses: Word count exceeds the 250-350 target at approximately 380 words, making it slightly less scannable than ideal
Section 2 (Brief Overview) does not explicitly include the impact metric in the recommended format ('Each project produces 12 high-quality habitat maps...' would be clearer than the current phrasing)
Some formal language is slightly verbose for the 8th-10th grade reading level target (e.g., 'play a crucial role in enhancing' could be 'strengthen' or 'improve')
The responsibilities section could include one more bullet (template suggests 4-6, only 5 provided) to mention the weekly check-in or collaboration expectations more explicitly
Minor: 'No stipends or reimbursements are provided' could be softened to 'No out-of-pocket costs' per the template guidance

outputs.content:
# GIS Mapping Analyst (Pro Bono)

## 1) Role Title
**GIS Mapping Analyst (Pro Bono)**

## 2) Brief Overview
You will create accurate, professional habitat maps that guide our field teams in restoring coastal ecosystems. Using ArcGIS Pro, you will analyze spatial data, produce cartographic products, and ensure data integrity. Each project deliverable helps produce 12 high-quality habitat maps guiding restoration across 1,500 acres, advancing our mission to protect and restore Pacific Coast habitats so wildlife and communities thrive.

## 3) Responsibilities
- Analyze ecological and geographic datasets (vegetation cover, species distribution, topography) using ArcGIS Pro
- Create 12 publication-ready habitat maps following Pacific Trails Conservancy brand standards and cartographic best practices
- Validate spatial data accuracy by cross-referencing field survey records and satellite imagery
- Document methodology and metadata to meet data governance standards
- Attend weekly check-in meetings to review progress and receive technical guidance
- Collaborate with conservation staff to ensure maps meet restoration planning needs

## 4) Time Commitment
Six hours per week for 12 weeks. Work on a flexible schedule that suits you. Attend one required weekly check-in meeting, Tuesdays 1:00–2:00 p.m. Pacific Time. Remote work from your location; optional desk space available at our San Francisco headquarters if preferred.

## 5) Qualifications
**Required:**
- Proficiency in ArcGIS Pro or ArcGIS Online
- Experience creating maps for professional or academic purposes
- Ability to work independently and meet deadlines

**Preferred:**
- Background in ecology, environmental science, geography, or related field
- Familiarity with ecological datasets (vegetation, wildlife, land cover)
- Knowledge of cartographic design principles
- Experience with data governance or quality control processes

Don't meet every preferred item? We encourage you to apply.

## 6) Training & Support
You will receive a project briefing, ArcGIS onboarding session, and data governance orientation. We provide an ArcGIS Pro license, comprehensive data dictionary, branded map templates, and secure data access. Weekly supervision and technical support from the Director of Conservation Data. No out-of-pocket costs.

## 7) Screening & Requirements
Volunteer agreement and confidentiality/non-disclosure agreement required. No background check required.

## 8) Inclusion & Accessibility
We welcome volunteers of all backgrounds and abilities. To request accommodations, contact Leah Chen, inclusion@pacifictrails.org, 415-555-0198.

## 9) Application Process & Contact
Apply at https://pacifictrails.org/volunteer/gis-analyst. You will hear from us within seven business days. Rolling start dates; next project kickoff is January 13, 2026.

Posted by Ravi Patel, Director of Conservation Data, 415-555-0172, ravi.patel@pacifictrails.org, Pacific Trails Conservancy.

evaluation.reasoning: This is a highly professional, well-structured volunteer role description that successfully balances formality with accessibility. It provides concrete, actionable information while maintaining the requested formal tone appropriate for a skilled pro bono position at an established conservation nonprofit. The output demonstrates strong adherence to the template and would be immediately usable by the organization.
strengths: Excellent specificity in responsibilities—tasks like 'Validate spatial data accuracy by cross-referencing field survey records and satellite imagery' are concrete and scannable, avoiding vague language
Strong impact framing that connects technical work to conservation outcomes (1,500 acres, habitat restoration)
Appropriate formal tone throughout that matches the professional nature of a GIS analyst role without becoming stiff or inaccessible
Complete and accurate inclusion of all 9 required sections with proper formatting and structure
Realistic qualifications section that keeps 'Required' minimal (only 3 items) while providing helpful 'Preferred' criteria and the encouraging disclaimer
Clear, honest time commitment details including the specific weekly meeting time and flexible work arrangement
Professional handling of training/support section that lists specific tools (ArcGIS Pro license, data dictionary, templates) rather than vague promises
weaknesses: Word count appears to exceed the 250-350 target (approximately 380-400 words), though content quality remains high
The phrase 'Each project deliverable helps produce 12 high-quality habitat maps' in section 2 is slightly awkward—could be streamlined to 'Your work will produce 12 high-quality habitat maps'

Minor authenticity concern: the language, while professional, occasionally feels slightly template-driven rather than organization-specific (e.g., 'publication-ready habitat maps' could include a brief example of how these are used)

outputs.content:
1) Role Title
GIS Mapping Analyst (Pro Bono)

2) Brief Overview
Support Pacific Trails Conservancy by producing clear, accurate habitat maps that guide restoration decisions along the Pacific Coast. You will turn complex spatial data into actionable insights for our field teams. Each shift helps Produce 12 high-quality habitat maps guiding restoration across 1,500 acres., advancing Protect and restore Pacific Coast habitats so wildlife and communities thrive..

3) Responsibilities
- Compile, clean, and standardize spatial datasets (e.g., vegetation, hydrology, parcels, trails) in ArcGIS Pro using our data dictionary.
- Produce 12 publication-quality habitat and restoration-priority maps using branded templates and symbology.
- Build and publish companion web maps/apps in ArcGIS Online; configure pop-ups, labels, and layer visibility.
- Run core spatial analyses (e.g., overlays, proximity, terrain/raster workflows) and document methods, assumptions, and parameters.
- Perform QA/QC, enter complete metadata, and manage versions per our data governance standards.
- Present progress at weekly check-ins and incorporate feedback from restoration and stewardship staff.

4) Time Commitment
Approximately 6 hours/week for 12 weeks. Flexible hours; weekly check-in Tuesdays 1–2 p.m. PT. Hybrid: remote work with an optional desk at our San Francisco HQ.

5) Qualifications
- Required:
  - Proficiency with ArcGIS Pro and ArcGIS Online for mapping and spatial analysis.
  - Ability to commit 6 hours/week for 12 weeks and attend the weekly check-in.
  - Reliable internet and a computer capable of running ArcGIS Pro (license provided).
- Preferred:
  - Experience with conservation or ecology datasets and restoration planning.
  - Strong cartographic design, metadata, and QA/QC practices.
  - ModelBuilder or Python/ArcPy; remote sensing/raster analysis.
  - Experience publishing web maps or dashboards.
  - Don’t meet every preferred item? We encourage you to apply.

6) Training & Support
Project briefing, ArcGIS Online/Pro onboarding, and data governance orientation. Supervision by the Director of Conservation Data. Resources provided: ArcGIS Pro license, data dictionary, branded map templates, and secure data access. No out-of-pocket costs. No stipends or reimbursements.

7) Screening & Requirements
Volunteer agreement and confidentiality/NDA required. No background check required.

8) Inclusion & Accessibility
We welcome volunteers of all backgrounds and abilities. To request accommodations, contact Leah Chen, inclusion@pacifictrails.org, 415-555-0198.

9) Application Process & Contact
Apply at pacifictrails.org/volunteer/gis-analyst (https://pacifictrails.org/volunteer/gis-analyst). We respond within 7 business days. Target start: rolling; next project kickoff January 13, 2026. Posted by Ravi Patel, Director of Conservation Data, 415-555-0172, ravi.patel@pacifictrails.org, Pacific Trails Conservancy.

evaluation.reasoning: The output follows the template structure meticulously and includes all required elements. However, it contains a critical formatting error in section 2 that makes it sound robotic, and the formal tone, while appropriate for a skilled pro bono role, occasionally feels stiff. The responsibilities are impressively specific and useful for recruiting qualified GIS professionals.
strengths: Excellent specificity in responsibilities—uses technical GIS terminology appropriately (ArcGIS Pro, ModelBuilder, ArcPy, raster workflows) that will resonate with qualified candidates
Comprehensive qualifications section that clearly distinguishes required vs. preferred skills and includes the encouraging 'Don't meet every preferred item?' language
Strong training and support section that lists concrete resources (license, templates, data dictionary) addressing common volunteer concerns
Appropriate formal tone for a skilled professional volunteer role at a large established organization
Complete contact information and clear application process with realistic timeline
weaknesses: Section 2 contains a glaring templating error: 'Each shift helps Produce 12 high-quality habitat maps...' with awkward capitalization and 'advancing Protect and restore...' that reads as unedited variable insertion—this is a major quality control failure
The phrase 'Each shift helps' is inappropriate for a 12-week skilled project (not shift-based work), revealing the template wasn't adapted for this volunteer type
Authenticity suffers from overly mechanical phrasing in places—'Run core spatial analyses' and the list format in responsibilities feels like a job description rather than a volunteer invitation
Word count appears to exceed the 250-350 target (approximately 380-400 words), reducing scannability
Section 6 redundantly states 'No out-of-pocket costs. No stipends or reimbursements' when one statement would suffice
